description: From condole +‎ -ence, or from Middle French condoléance, or formed from the root of Latin condoleō (“I sympathize”), from con- (“together, with”) and doleō (“I hurt, suffer, have pain”).

examples: There was not much to do after the accident but offer what condolence I could.

entries.meaning: (countable, usually in the plural) An expression of comfort, support, or sympathy offered to the family and friends of somebody who has died.
examples: I sent her a card expressing my condolences after her mother passed away.
